alertitem.desc: The API returns sensitive data to the client by design. This data is usually filtered on the client side before being presented to the user. An attacker can easily sniff the traffic and see the sensitive data.\n
alertitem.solution: Review the responses from the API to make sure they contain only legitimate data. Classify sensitive and personally identifiable information (PII) that your application stores and works with, reviewing all API calls returning such information to see if these responses pose a security issue.\n

alertitem.alert: UnAuthenticated Access by emptying attribute on http.request.header.authorization
alertitem.desc: Traceable identified an Unauthenticated Access vulnerability.\nAuthentication is the process of verifying that an individual, entity or website is whom it claims to be. Authentication in the context of web applications is commonly performed by submitting a username or ID and one or more items of private information that only a given user should know. Authentication mechanisms are often implemented incorrectly, allowing attackers to compromise authentication tokens or to exploit implementation flaws to assume other user\'s identities temporarily or permanently. Compromising system\'s ability to identify the client/user, compromises API security overall.\n
alertitem.solution:
The best way to protect your code against Unauthenticated Access is to implement authentication checks and session management.
- Use popular authentication libraries instead of architecting your own.
- Rotate credentials regularly.
- Expire session tokens in a short time.
- Rate limit your authentication endpoints including registration, login, password recovery, session management etc.
- Reauthenticate for critical operations.

alertitem.desc: Traceable identified there is no TLS support for the domain in test. \nTLS (Transport Layer Security) is a protocol that provides secure communication over the Internet and is used to encrypt communication between web browsers and web servers. If a web/API server does not support TLS, any communication with that server is not encrypted and can be intercepted by a malicious third party. This vulnerability can lead to data theft, account hijacking, and other security risks.\n
alertitem.solution: The best way to mitigate this vulnerability is to ensure that the web server is configured to support TLS. This can be done by ensuring that the web server is running a supported version of TLS, and that any webpages that require secure communication are enabled to use TLS. Additionally, web administrators should ensure that the server is regularly updated and that any vulnerabilities that may have been discovered are patched. Finally, web administrators should ensure that all sensitive data is encrypted using TLS before it is transmitted.\n
